Key Arguments: The proposed Bill imposes onerous demands and penalties on digital platform providers, leading to potential over-censorship.
The Bill is seen as an attack on democratic principles by allowing an unelected body, ACMA, to determine what constitutes misinformation or disinformation.
The Bill undermines the ability of Australians to engage in free and informed debate on controversial issues.
The exclusion of government-authorized content from scrutiny is viewed as unjustifiable and contrary to democratic accountability.
Notable Quotes: The onerous demands of the rules placed on digital platform providers and the penalties for breaches of those demands would cause those providers to avoid any content which could be interpreted by ACMA as 'misinformation' or 'disinformation'.
This proposed Bill attacks the principles of democracy.

The vast majority of Australians have the capacity to decide for themselves what is for their own common good, and do not need ACMA, or any other body for that matter, to be assigned the extreme degree of power which this Bill proposes.
This Bill proposes that content authorised by our Government is to be excluded from this scrutiny. This is an unjustifiable decision...
